instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID_R: What is SMC_LID_R? SMC_LID_R is the signal coming from the hall sensor that detects whether the laptop screen is closed or open. This must be high in order for SMC_LID to be high. SMC_LID has to be high for the machine to not fall asleep and for it to have a backlight..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476A: What is 820-3476A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message:
Hey all i got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Previously water damage after wash everything working well, except when you close the lid the macbook apple light does not turn off and macbook does not sleep. So i opened her up to inspect around <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_R</SIGNAL> and found few components are burnt out and corroded.

on the J5250 there is a small cap which was badly corroded. I looked on schematics and couldnt find the specifications on it. Does anyone know or can help me so I can replace it?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: Dont know but you can take it from donor board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: Got a photo of it? Does it work/behave if you don't have the cap there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message:
No Title

I wonder if that's the cap you're referring to? 1nF 50V 0402.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: Yeah, thats the one mate. I measured one from a working board which presented 100nF which would be 0.1uF? definately 0402 and no harm using 50v right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message:
Given that it looks like its primary purpose is just to be a noise squelch,  you probably should be fine with anything from 1nF~100nF, though replacing it with 1nF 50V would be preferred of course since that's the original value.     

I'd say the 100nF reading you got was because of the rest of the collective capacitance, between the traces/board-layers/connectors/pins.  50V rating might be simply because it was easier to utilise an existing value used elsewhere on the board, but certainly try stay with 1nF/50V if you can. 

Does it work without it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: jsut tried without. no sleep mode. i will try with 50v rating. c what happens. thanks paul

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: yerp tried with 1nf 10% 50v not working. gunna look elsewhere

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message:
Guess you'll have to debug that net in more detail. Perhaps there's a continuity break to the SMC? What voltage do you get on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> when open, vs when closed?

What's the diode-mode value of the line? (red to ground).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: Probably corrosion under LID board, do a continuity test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: Does <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> go low when you hold a magnet over the Hall sensor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message:
broken trace. fixed. i got the same issue on another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> however it is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
My question is the resistor on the <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_R</SIGNAL>? can i bypass that? its only 0ohm? whats the point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a j5250
threads.message: 0 Ohm resistor can be jumped if it does not carry any current and is not meant as a fuse. In this case it is in a signal line so can be jumped. It may have been there for an R/C delay/filter that was scrapped after the board was finished.
